source.name: City of Edinburgh Council
source.notes: Based on official City of Edinburgh Council bin guidelines. Multi-bin system: green (mixed recycling), recycling box (glass + small electricals + textiles), grey food bin, brown garden bin, grey general. Food must be bagged.

materials.name: Paper and unwanted mail
instructions: Place in green wheelie bin (mixed recycling)
notes: Includes newspapers, leaflets, letters, and junk mail
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or kitchen roll — those go in the grey non-recyclable bin

materials.name: Newspapers and magazines
notes: Glossy and non-glossy paper both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Cardboard and drinks cartons
notes: Drinks cartons (Tetra Pak) accepted in Edinburgh's green bin
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily soiled cardboard

materials.name: Envelopes
instructions: Window envelopes are fine — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Standard and window envelopes accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include bubble-lined padded envelopes; those go in the grey bin

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: Caps can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them

materials.name: Plastic pots, tubs, and trays
notes: Must be clean — food residue contaminates recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include black plastic trays if heavily soiled
Don't include plastic plant pots — those go in the grey bin

materials.name: Food tins and cans
notes: Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include tins with food still in them

materials.name: Drinks cans
notes: Aluminium and steel cans both accepted
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans flat

materials.name: Aluminium foil
notes: Must be clean; heavily soiled foil goes in grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil with baked-on grease

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurised — take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Place in recycling box (not the green bin)
notes: Glass goes in the recycling box, NOT the green wheelie bin
Metal lids can go in the green wheelie bin
commonMistakes: Don't put glass in the green wheelie bin
Don't include broken glass, light bulbs, or Pyrex

materials.name: Small electrical items
notes: Edinburgh accepts small electricals in the kerbside recycling box
Item must fit in the box
commonMistakes: Don't include large electricals — take those to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
Don't include batteries separately — tape terminals and bag them

materials.name: Household batteries
instructions: Place in a clear plastic bag
Set bag on top of recycling box on collection day
notes: Batteries must be in a clear bag on top of the box, not inside it
commonMistakes: Don't put loose batteries in any bin
Don't include car batteries — take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre

materials.name: Clothing, towels, sheets, and shoes
instructions: Place in a tied plastic bag
Put the bag in the recycling box
notes: Must be bagged to keep dry
Paired shoes accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include duvets or pillows — those go in the grey bin
Don't include wet or heavily soiled textiles

materials.name: Cooked food waste
instructions: Must be bagged (use compostable liner or newspaper)
notes: All cooked food accepted including meat and fish
commonMistakes: Don't put unbagged food in the caddy
Don't include packaging

materials.name: Uncooked food waste
notes: All raw food including meat, fish, and bones accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put food waste in the grey non-recyclable bin

materials.name: Tea bags
notes: Most tea bags contain a small amount of plastic, but Edinburgh accepts them in food waste
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place grounds and paper filter in grey food caddy
notes: Paper filters are accepted with the grounds
commonMistakes: Don't include coffee pods unless emptied

materials.name: Bread and baked goods
notes: Includes mouldy bread
commonMistakes: Don't include packaging

materials.name: Dairy waste
notes: Small amounts of liquid dairy accepted
commonMistakes: Don't pour large amounts of liquid into the caddy
Recycle the container separately

materials.name: Meat, fish, and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or place in compostable bag
notes: All meat and fish scraps accepted, including bones
commonMistakes: Don't put in the grey non-recyclable bin

materials.name: Garden flowers and plants
instructions: Place in brown wheelie bin (garden waste)
notes: Brown bin collected fortnightly, March to November
commonMistakes: Don't include soil or stones
Don't include plant pots

materials.name: Grass clippings
notes: Don't overfill — bin lid must close
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Hedge and shrub clippings
instructions: Cut to fit in brown wheelie bin
notes: Small branches and twigs accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include large branches or tree trunks
Don't include treated wood

materials.name: Fallen leaves
notes: Seasonal — brown bin collected March to November
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic

materials.name: Plastic bags, wrappers, and cling film
notes: Not accepted in Edinburgh's kerbside recycling
Some supermarkets accept carrier bags for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin — they jam sorting machinery

materials.name: Paper towels and kitchen roll
notes: Not accepted in Edinburgh's green recycling bin or food caddy
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic plant pots
notes: Not accepted in Edinburgh's kerbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic toys
instructions: If in good condition, donate to charity shop
notes: Not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin
Remove batteries first

materials.name: Nappies and sanitary products
instructions: Bag and place in grey non-recyclable bin
notes: Not compostable or recyclable in Edinburgh
commonMistakes: Don't put in the food caddy or green bin

materials.name: Polystyrene and styrofoam
notes: Not accepted in any Edinburgh recycling stream
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: Wrap carefully and place in grey non-recyclable bin
notes: Energy-saving (CFL) and fluorescent tubes should go to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling box with glass bottles

materials.name: Glass dishes, Pyrex, and ceramics
notes: Different type of glass to bottles/jars — cannot be recycled together
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling box

materials.name: Broken glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in thick newspaper or cardboard
notes: Broken glass is a safety hazard for collection crews
commonMistakes: Don't put loose broken glass in any bin

materials.name: Duvets and pillows
instructions: Place in grey non-recyclable bin or take to Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Not accepted in the recycling box (unlike clothing/textiles)
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling box

materials.name: Large electrical appliances
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
Or arrange a special uplift through Edinburgh Council
notes: Edinburgh Council offers a bulky waste collection service (may be chargeable)
commonMistakes: Don't put at the kerbside without booking a collection
Don't include in any wheeled bin

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Edinburgh has Household Waste Recycling Centres at Bankhead and Seafield
commonMistakes: Don't put liquid paint in any bin
Don't pour down the drain or into the garden

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Never pour down drains
commonMistakes: Don't pour into drains or soil

materials.name: Medicines and pharmaceuticals
notes: Most pharmacies in Edinburgh accept unused medicines
commonMistakes: Don't flush down the toilet
Don't put in any bin

materials.name: Cooking oil and fat
instructions: Small amounts: soak onto kitchen roll and place in grey bin
Large amounts: take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Never pour down the drain — causes fatbergs
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the sink

materials.name: Large cardboard boxes
instructions: Place beside or in the green wheelie bin
If too large, take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Must be flattened to avoid taking up bin space
commonMistakes: Don't leave unflattened boxes beside the bin

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag or envelope
notes: Loose shredded paper blows away and can't be sorted
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the bin

materials.name: Books
instructions: If damaged, place in green wheelie bin
notes: Charity shops welcome books in good condition
commonMistakes: Don't bin usable books

materials.name: Egg boxes (cardboard)
notes: Cardboard egg boxes only — polystyrene ones go in grey bin
commonMistakes: Don't include polystyrene egg boxes

materials.name: Bubble wrap and packing materials
notes: Not accepted in kerbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Crisp packets and snack wrappers
notes: Metallised film — not recyclable at kerbside
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Thermal receipts
notes: Thermal paper contains BPA and contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
notes: Lined paper cups are not recyclable at kerbside in Edinburgh
Some coffee shops offer cup recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin
Lid may be recyclable separately if it's plastic

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If clean or lightly soiled: flatten and place in green wheelie bin
If heavily greased: place in grey non-recyclable bin
notes: Light grease is OK; heavy saturation is not
commonMistakes: Don't include boxes soaked through with grease

materials.name: Tetra Pak and drinks cartons
notes: Edinburgh accepts Tetra Pak cartons in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't leave liquid inside

materials.name: Car batteries
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
Some garages and motor factors accept them
notes: Contains lead and acid — extremely hazardous
commonMistakes: Never put in any household bin

materials.name: Medium electronics
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
Or use a WEEE recycling point
notes: Delete personal data before recycling
Many charities accept working electronics
commonMistakes: Don't put in the grey bin

materials.name: Plastic cutlery
notes: Too small for sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling bin

materials.name: Plastic straws
notes: Too small for recycling equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put in green recycling bin

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: If it passes the 'scrunch test' (stays scrunched): green wheelie bin
If foil-backed or glittery: grey non-recyclable bin
notes: Plain paper wrapping is recyclable; metallic or glittery is not
commonMistakes: Don't include sellotape — remove where possible

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the grey non-recyclable bin

materials.name: Leftover pet food
notes: Treat the same as any other food waste
commonMistakes: Recycle the tin separately in the green bin

materials.name: Wax paper and baking parchment
notes: Wax and silicone coatings prevent recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Book a special uplift through Edinburgh Council
Or take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Special uplift service available (may be chargeable)
commonMistakes: Don't leave at the kerbside without booking

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL bulbs
instructions: Take to a Household Waste Recycling Centre
notes: Contains mercury — must not go in household bins
commonMistakes: Don't put in the grey bin or recycling box

materials.name: Metal lids and bottle caps
notes: Small metal items accepted
commonMistakes: Remove from glass jars before putting glass in recycling box

materials.name: Soft plastic film and bags
instructions: Some supermarkets have soft plastic collection points
notes: Not accepted in kerbside recycling in Edinburgh
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green recycling bin

recycle: Paper, newspapers, magazines, and unwanted mail (green bin)
Cardboard boxes and drinks cartons including Tetra Pak (green bin)
Clean plastic bottles with tops on (green bin)
Clean plastic pots, tubs, and trays (green bin)
Food tins, drinks cans, and empty aerosols (green bin)
Small electrical items — hairdryers, toasters, irons (recycling box)
Household batteries in a clear bag on top of recycling box
Clothing, towels, sheets, and shoes in a plastic bag (recycling box)
Shredded paper in a paper bag (green bin)
compost: All cooked and uncooked food waste — must be bagged (grey food caddy)
Tea bags and coffee grounds (grey food caddy)
Meat, fish, and bones (grey food caddy)
Garden flowers, grass clippings, hedge trimmings (brown bin)
trash: Plastic bags, cling film, and wrappers (grey bin)
Paper towels and kitchen roll (grey bin)
Plastic plant pots and toys (grey bin)
Light bulbs, Pyrex, glass dishes, and broken glass (grey bin)

recycle: Plastic bags, wrappers, cling film, or crisp packets
Glass (must go in recycling box, not green bin)
Batteries and small electricals (recycling box, not green bin)
Light bulbs, Pyrex, glass dishes, broken glass, or ceramics
compost: Garden waste in the food caddy (use brown bin for garden waste)

tips: Edinburgh has a multi-bin system: green wheelie bin (mixed recycling), recycling box (glass + electricals + textiles + batteries), grey food caddy, brown garden bin, grey non-recyclable bin
Green wheelie bin is for paper, card, plastic bottles/pots/tubs/trays, tins, cans, foil, and aerosols — NOT glass
Glass bottles and jars go in the recycling box only
Small electricals and batteries go in/on the recycling box
Food waste must be bagged before going in the grey food caddy
Brown garden waste bin is collected fortnightly, March to November
Use Edinburgh Council's recycling sorter at edinburgh.gov.uk for specific items
Household Waste Recycling Centres at Bankhead and Seafield accept bulky and hazardous waste

locations.name: Bankhead Household Waste Recycling Centre
locations.notes: Bankhead Drive, Edinburgh — check website for opening hours

locations.name: Seafield Household Waste Recycling Centre
locations.notes: Marine Esplanade, Edinburgh — check website for opening hours
